Award.AwardTitle: Symposium on Advances in Multidisciplinary Engineering; International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Expo; Houston, Texas; November 13-19, 2015

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant provides partial funding for a special Symposium to be held in conjunction with the International Mechanical Engineering Congress and Expo, November 13-19, 2015, in Houston, Texas. The overall event, the ASME Annual Congress, is organized by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers (ASME) and is perhaps the foremost conference covering the broad range of fields that comprise mechanical engineering: applied mechanics, thermal and fluid systems, heat transfer, materials engineering, engineering design, energy, manufacturing, and engineering education. This Track is focused on Advances in Multidisciplinary Engineering.

The Symposium on Advances in Multidisciplinary Engineering will highlight the importance of the multidisciplinary approach in engineering research, design, and education. The symposium will focus on Mechanical Behavior of Materials, Tribology, Cutting Tools and Machining, Polymer Processing, Design Theory, Complexity Theory and Multidisciplinary Engineering Education. A diverse and international group of individuals from academia and industry will participate in the panel discussions to identify future challenges and research needs from both industrial and academic perspectives. Papers will be published on the DVD issued by the ASME and included, along with the summary recommendations of two discussion panels and the abstracts of the presentations that do not include full manuscripts, in the printed proceedings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multidisciplinary Engineering can be defined as an engineering practice that synergistically combines concepts from various single engineering disciplines. Many complex problems require “Multidisciplinary” approaches that do not lend themselves to single traditional engineering disciplines.  Throughout the career, Prof. Suh at MIT has been an innovator in taking concepts from different disciplines and applying them to solve complex problems in engineering for real practices. A most well know case is his introduction of the "Delamination Theory of Wear "- taking concepts from materials science and contact mechanics and combining them to explain the wear process in metals. Another example is his concept of "On-Line Electric Vehicles" for public transport that uses buried electric field over which the vehicles charge batteries and travel, thus providing a sustainable and clean energy source for transportation. His multi-disciplinary achievements grew from his innovative Axiomatic Design Theory and the Theory of Complexity. A special Symposium was organized as a Track in conjunction with the International Mechanical Engineering Congress & Expo, November 13-19, 2015 in Houston TX, USA., which featured plenary presentations from renowned and internationally recognized leaders followed by a series of presentations, mostly invited, from the leaders in the selected topics in Tribology, Manufacturing and Productivity, Polymer Processing, Design of Complex Systems, Sustainability and Manufacturing, and Engineering Education.

A diverse and international group of individuals from both academia and industry participated in the symposium and a book "Advances in Multidisciplinary Engineering" has been published as an outcome of this event.  Funding from NSF was used effiectively to support students and early-career engineers to the regular sessions and the panel discussions as well as for publication of the proceedings of this special event. The published proceedings include the panel summaries as guidelines for future research and education in Multidisciplinary Engineering with a broad potential impact for the society as a whole.
